critique: This document pertains to the administration and governance of the Panama Canal Zone in 1955. It primarily deals with the chain of command and responsibilities within the Canal Zone government, specifically designating the Secretary of the Army to supervise the Governor and establishing the position of Lieutenant Governor. There's no indication of ideological leaning (liberal vs. conservative), immigration policy, or social inclusion. It touches upon federalism by clarifying the roles of federal officers in the zone. It doesn't directly address national security vs. civil liberties or economic regulation. The executive power aspect is somewhat neutral, as it's more about internal organization than expanding presidential authority. Therefore, most axes should be scored as neutral (0), with a slight lean towards federal control (+1) due to the federal government's oversight of the Canal Zone.
